columns.text: In this problem, we will solve for the profitability index of the project.

In the previous problem, we already solved for the cash flows for Year 1-3. Now we will solve for Year 4 and 5 by taking the earnings, adding the depreciation, then subtracting tax and net working capital cash flow. The net working capital is $20\%$ of the sales for that year.

Substituting the values for the net cash flow in the previous problem and the net cash flow for Year 4 and 5, we will get the profitability index. In this we will use $r=0.12$ since this is the required return:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Profitability index}&=\dfrac{\$8,338,641.50}{(1+0.12)^1}+\dfrac{\$25,762,911.50}{(1+0.12)^2}\\
&+\dfrac{\$27,427,961.50}{(1+0.12)^3}+\dfrac{\$23,933,505.50}{(1+0.12)^4}+\dfrac{\$16,563,505.50}{(1+0.12)^5}\\[15 pt]
&=\$72,114,685.44
\end{aligned}$$

The numerator for the profitability index is $\$72,114,685.44$

Now that we have the numerator, we can now divide this by the initial investment to get the profitability index.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Profitability Index}&=\dfrac{\$72,114,685.44}{\$43,500,000}\\[15 pt]
&=1.659
\end{aligned}$$

A profitability index of $1$ means that the project will break even. A value greater than one indicates that the project will be profitable. In the case of this project, since its profitability index is $1.659$, we can say that it is indeed profitable.
